review.title: Intelligent Conversational Bot for Massive Online Open Courses (MOOCs)
review.abstract: Massive Online Open Courses (MOOCs) which were introduced in 2008 has since drawn attention around the world for both its advantages as well as criticism on its drawbacks. One of the issues in MOOCs which is the lack of interactivity with the instructor has brought conversational bot into the picture to fill in this gap. In this study, a prototype of MOOCs conversational bot, MOOC-bot is being developed and integrated into MOOCs website to respond to the learner inquiries using text or speech input. MOOC-bot is using the popular Artificial Intelligence Markup Language (AIML) to develop its knowledge base, leverage from AIML capability to deliver appropriate responses and can be quickly adapted to new knowledge domains. The system architecture of MOOC-bot consists of knowledge base along with AIML interpreter, chat interface, MOOCs website and Web Speech API to provide speech recognition and speech synthesis capability. The initial MOOC-bot prototype has the general knowledge from the past Loebner Prize winner - ALICE, frequent asked questions, and a content offered by Universiti Teknikal Malaysia Melaka (UTeM). The evaluation of MOOC-bot based on the past competition questions from Chatterbox Challenge (CBC) and Loebner Prize has shown that it was able to provide correct answers most of the time during the test and demonstrated the capability to prolong the conversation. The advantages of MOOC-bot such as able to provide 24-hour service that can serve different time zones, able to have knowledge in multiple domains, and can be shared by multiple sites simultaneously have outweighed its existing limitations.

sections.text: The MOOC-bot has a knowledge base together with an AIML interpreter, a chat interface, the MOOCs website and the Web Speech API to provide appropriate answers and be quickly adapted to new areas of knowledge. MOOC-Boat's system architecture consists of a knowledge base together with an AIML interpreter, a chat interface, a MOOCs website and a Web Speech API to provide speech recognition and speech synthesis.

sections.heading: 1.1 Background
sections.text: In recent years, a diversified form of online learning has also emerged, growing exponentially from 2008 to 2013 (Aparicio et. al., 2014).MOOCs were first introduced in 2008 and many universities have since adopted it. Prominent MOOCs providers include Coursera, edX and Udacity, which also grew exponentially from 2008 to 2013. Unlike Andrew Ng and Daphne Koller of Stanford University, Coursera founded a platform on which Ng taught machine learning.

sections.heading: 1.2 Statement of the Purpose
sections.text: The purpose of this research is to develop a conversation boat for MOOC as a Courseversational Bot using AIML. The target course for this research would be "MITI 5113 Artificial Intelligence," offered by UTeM.

sections.heading: 1.3 Problem Statement
sections.text: MOOCs are a new online learning model that can accommodate a huge number of participants, as evidenced by Stanford University's 2011 MOOC "Artificial Intelligence," where there were 160,000 enrolments (Iqbal et. al., 2014). Since normally only one instructor holds a course, students will not be able to receive the full attention or help of the instructor when they encounter problems, which will ultimately be frustrating for students. On the other hand, faculty will feel overwhelmed to process so many student requests at once. Moreover, it is inefficient for the instructor to repeat the answers many times, causing additional workload. In addition, MOOCs are designed to provide students with flexibility to learn for their own convenience because they may have a full-time job or other obligations, while offering MOOCs to participants from around the world, meaning they can live in locations with different time zones.

sections.heading: 1.4 Research Questions
sections.text: Based on the issues mentioned in Section 1.3, the research questions for this study are identified as follows: 1. Can the MOOC bot synthesize the questions the user asks in text or language? 2. Can the MOOC bot give the answer in text and language? 3. Can the MOOC bot adequately provide the answers and prolong the conversation?

sections.heading: 1.5 Research Objective
sections.text: The research objectives relate to the research questions. This results in the following search objectives: 1. Synthesize the questions asked by the users using text or speech input; 2. Provide answers to questions in text and language; 3. Ensure that MOOC-Bot is able to provide adequate answers and prolong the conversation with the users.

sections.heading: 1.6 Research Scope and Limitation
sections.text: This research will have the scope and limitations of: 1) This research focuses on one of the courses offered by UTeM, namely "MITI5113 Artificial Intelligence." 2) The questions that can be answered must be within the MOOC bot knowledge base. 3) The question to be answered must be text or voice input in English. 4) Voice input and voice responses are supported only with Google Chrome or Apple Safari web browsers.

sections.heading: 1.7 Significant and Research Contribution
sections.text: This research aims to provide a solution to overcome the existing shortcomings of MOOCs with a Conversation bot. The Conversation bot can be used in various courses as its knowledge can be added and adapted. It also has the great advantage of providing students with a tireless 24-hour service, which is a great help in MOOCs. In addition, the Conversation bot offers the convenience of accepting text or voice input, and the answers can also be in text and language.

sections.heading: 1.8 Organization of the Thesis
sections.text: This work is divided into the following order: Chapter 1: IntroductionThis chapter presents the background of the MOOCs, the problems that this topic faces, the proposed solution and the objectives of this research.Chapter 2: Literature valuationThis chapter covers the literature on MOOCs and the proposed solution, which in this case is the conversational bot and the related fields.Chapter 3: Research methodIn this chapter, the methods used in this research to achieve the objectives and the system architecture.Chapter 4: ImplementationThis chapter explains the process of implementing the system architecture and developing the prototype. Chapter 5: Evaluation and resultsThis chapter explains how the evaluation is carried out and the results of the evaluation.Chapter 6: Conclusion and future workplacesThis chapter concludes the overall study, discusses the strengths and weaknesses and the recommendation for future work.CHAPTEL 2LITERATURE REVIEW

sections.heading: 2.1 Introduction
sections.text: This chapter discusses massive open online courses (MOOCs), conversation messages, and related topics. Artificial intelligence (AI) is the area of study that inspires the exploration of many useful applications with a computer or machine, and one of these is conversation messages. Conversational messages are sometimes referred to as conversation robots, conversation agents, chatbots, chatterbots, or simply "bots," but they have the same goal, which is to generate meaningful conversations with human users in natural language. To this end, Turing Test (TT) is the known measurement used to evaluate the performance of a conversation bot, and many parties use TT as an assessment of conversation messengers such as the Loebner Prize and Chatterbox Challenge contest, although it is the modified version of the original TT. There are many types of conversation messengers that have been researched and developed over the years, ranging from general conversation messengers that may not specialize in conversation bots, to those that can be used for such conversations.

sections.heading: 2.3 Artificial Intelligence
sections.text: The term "artificial intelligence" (AI) was first introduced at a workshop at Dartmouth College in 1956, which saw the need to separate it from other fields of study (Russell and Norvig, 2010). AI is a branch of computer science that attempts to create intelligent machines that may exhibit behavior similar to human intelligence. Essentially, it is an attempt to simulate the intelligence of the human mind. According to Russell and Norvig (2010), the AI system can be divided into four categories, namely human thought, rational action, human action, and rational action, as shown in Figure 2.1. Today, AI is used in many areas. Some of the examples are natural language comprehension, speech recognition, planning and planning, vision, robotics, and expert systems. There have been many successes or successful applications in AI history.

sections.heading: 2.4 Turing Test, Loebner Prize and Chatterbox Challenge
sections.text: Alan Turing was a very influential pioneer in computer science and a brilliant mathematician who surpassed the required data storage. In 1950, through his famous article "Computing Machinery and Intelligence," he proposed a behavioral intelligence test, which he called the "Imitation Game." However, his challenge to "Can machines think?" in the newspaper brought attention to the point of view of machine intelligence. The test, better known as the Turing Test (TT), suggested that a computer is considered "intelligent" if a human questioner who asked some written questions cannot tell whether the written answers come from a human or a computer, as illustrated in Figure 2.3.Turing (1950), believed that in about fifty years from that date (which should be assumed, year 2000), computers will have reached the storage capacity of about 109 that would reach the result of the test: "an average interrogator will not have more than 70 percent chance of correctly identifying."

sections.heading: 2.5 Conversational Bots
sections.text: It was developed by Weizenbaum (1966) to play the role of a psychotherapist to a patient. This research was considered a breakthrough in AI at the time because it showed a form of communication between human and computer in natural language. Although ELIZA was far from passing the real TT, but was able to convince the questioner to continue the conversation with the program, it led people to believe that it had shown the reactions in a Turing-like test. Figure 2.4 shows a sample dialogue of ELIZA from Wheat Tree (1966).How ELIZA simulated a Roman psychotherapist, it was able to rephrase the trick of presenting the patient's statements as questions and the patient will likely open up his personal problems that will continue the conversation. Weizenbaum was surprised that his program could also deceive normal people into believing (Saygin et al.).

sections.heading: 2.6 Artificial Intelligence Mark-up Language (AIML)
sections.text: It is a derivative of XML with a specific structure. As an XML-compliant language, AIML should also respect the grammar specification in XML, such as the syntax of comments, white space handling, end-of-line handling, the need for the closing tag, and so on. An AIML file should be saved with "aiml" extension, for example: "bot.aiml" and it must include "< aiml >" tag in the file. "The" < aiml > "tag can include the AIML version as shown in Figure 2.10 to avoid confusion, as there is more than one version like 1.0, 1.0.1 and the latest is 2.0, whose specification is under draft (Wallace, 2014).The basic unit of knowledge in AIML."

sections.heading: 2.7 Web Speech Application Programming Language (API)
sections.text: Web Speech API provides a JavaScript interface for developers to integrate speech recognition and speech synthesis into web applications. Speech recognition is an alternative input method that works by accepting speech input and converting it to text. Voice input has several advantages, for example, it improves accessibility for visually impaired users and provides a hands-free input method (Adorf, 2013). On the other hand, speech synthesis is the act of converting text to speech. Voice synthesis is integrated into Text-to-Speech (TTS) applications to provide a better user experience.Although the specification of the Web Speech API is included in HyperText MarkupLanguage 5 (HTML5), it is currently only supported by Google Chrome and Apple Safari browsers (Walther, 2015).One of the drawbacks of the Web Speech API is that the user of the application is allowed to use the microphone for voice recognition.

sections.heading: 2.8 Summary
sections.text: This chapter gives an overview of MOOCs from a few perspectives, such as types of MOOCs, advantages and challenges. One of the problems in MOOCs is the lack of interactivity with the instructor who brought the conversation bot into the picture to fill this gap. Conversational bot, which is considered part of the application of AI, is always measured in the Turing test planned by Alan Turing. Although some may have criticized TT as a focal point in AI research, the Loebner Prize and Chatterbox Challenge competition has kept it alive over the past 20 years, with annual prizes to attract participants. To date, the Loebner Prize grand prize has not been claimed, but the techniques in the conversation bot have evolved with AIML by ALICE as one of the most powerful outcomes. AIML may not be a completely intelligent technology, but its ability to provide adequate answers in domain-restricted areas (Schumaker etal, 2006; Miketal. OLICE, Baretan, 2012-OCHER, and MEZ-GER) is sufficient.

sections.heading: 3.1 Introduction
sections.text: The research methodology is important to solve the research problem systematically. This chapter describes the methodology and design used in this research with the aim of building a MOOC bot prototype. Having reviewed the AIML technology in the previous chapter, it is now applied in the MOOC bot to play the role of a conversation boat that can respond to course-related queries. The prototype of the MOOC bot has the domain knowledge of the "MITI 5113 Artificial Intelligence" course taught at the UTeM.

sections.heading: 3.2 Type of Research Method
sections.text: This study is based on qualitative research because it is not as easy to quantify as quantitative research requires. Initially used mainly in psychology and the social sciences, the use of qualitative research has increased in recent decades due to trends towards empirical research in conjunction with modernity (Flick, 2009). Qualitative research is an approach that includes inductive data analysis and data interpretation by the researcher (Creswell, 2013), many of which are carried out by qualitative methods for research with talking robots (Benotti et. al., 2014; Ghose et Barua et.al., 2013; Dybala et.al., 2009), since turing tests popular among researchers in this field are also based on qualitative assessment (Browne, 1991).

sections.heading: 3.3 Research Design
sections.text: To build MOOC robots, the software development model of the prototype is used to ensure rapid development in a more cost-effective manner. Prototype is a direct method to provide users with the image of the proposed system. According to Pressman and Maxim (2014), prototype evaluated by the user can be used to refine the requirements of the software. Prototype can be customized to meet the requirements of the user and at the same time the developer can have a better understanding of the requirements based on feedback. The changes and suggestions that are made at the prototype stage can avoid sudden changes after completion of the system.Prototype methodology has two strategies: requirement prototype, which is also known as disposable prototype, and evolutionary prototype. The development of MOOCbot would be using evolutionary prototype prototype, because the prototype is being discarded to a prototype.

sections.heading: 3.3.1 Planning Phase
sections.text: The evolutionary prototype methodology was chosen for its advantage in providing end-users with a working model to better understand how MOOC-Bot would work before the complete system. MOOC's existing problems are identified and described in Chapter 1.

sections.heading: 3.3.2 Analysis Phase
sections.text: This phase will examine the specification of the system to be developed on the basis of the problems identified in the planning phase, such as the need to serve a large number of learners and provide a 24-hour service for students from different time zones. Knowledge required for this prototype, such as the contents of the "Artificial Intelligence" course and basic general knowledge, can be obtained at: i) Lecture Notes The lecture notes will be provided by the tutor of this course.ii) Book The main reference work of the course is "Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach" (Russell and Novig, 2010).iii) Annotated ALICE AIML (AAA) FilesThe AAA files provided by the ALICE AI Foundation contain a lot of general knowledge that should be sufficient for MOOC-Bot to conduct general conversations.

sections.heading: 3.3.3 Design Phase
sections.text: After identifying the user specifications in the analysis phase, the prototype design can be created. Design is the system architecture of the MOOC bot, consisting of chat interface, knowledge base, AIML interpreter and MOOC website. Detailed description of the system architecture is explained in 3.4.

sections.heading: 3.3.4 Prototype Development Phase
sections.text: The first prototype, which meets the basic requirements, will be developed and shown to the tutor; the second prototype will be integrated into the MOOC website; this prototype will be able to collect results from the use of users on the website by referring to the conversation logs stored in the database; the second prototype will then be carried out by improving the first prototype knowledge base by analysing the conversation logs; the second prototype will repeat the same process as the first prototype; the last prototype, which will be able to answer most questions rationally, will be a real system.Development will take place in the Windows system and can be tested using a local web server client environment; this can be done by installing the Apache web server on Windows; the WampServer package, which can be downloaded from the Internet, can automatically create Apache, Hypertext Preprocessor (PHP) and MySQL database on Windows.

sections.heading: 3.3.5 Prototype Testing Phase
sections.text: In this case, the MOOC bot should be able to answer questions related to the domain knowledge that is the content of the course and some of the general questions. This test can be performed by using some of the past questions posed by the jurors in the Conversation bot competition, such as the Loebner Prize and the Chatterbox Challenge Competition.

sections.heading: 3.4 System Architecture
sections.text: MOOC-bot is built into MOOC-bot's website as a chat interface, just like any other web application, it operates according to the client-server concept; the MOOCs website and AIML interpreter are hosted on the Apache web server, while the database and knowledge base use MySQL, which runs on the server; the web server works by translating PHP codes into the HyperText Markup Language (HTML), while the web client such as Internet Explorer, Google Chrome, etc. translates the client script like JavaScript before it is displayed to the user. If the user uses Google Chrome browser and opts for speech recognition, the Web Speech API converts language into text before it is sent to the AIML interpreter, displaying the result in text and language; the general database is used to save web-related information such as the user profile, the course and so on.

sections.heading: 3.4.1 Chat Interface
sections.text: The chat interface of the MOOC bot is integrated into the MOOC website, and the chat interface is located at the bottom of the website as shown in Figure 3.3. The function of the chat interface is to receive text or voice input from the user and forward it to the AIML interpreter. In order to detect speech, the user must press the microphone button and allow the application to receive voice input, and the results of the interpreter are displayed and read to users when the speaker is turned on. Figure 3.4 shows the chat interface itself.

sections.heading: 3.4.2 Knowledge Base
sections.text: The knowledge of the MOOC bot consists of the knowledge of the course, the FAQ of the course and the general knowledge derived from AAA files. Knowledge of the course is "Artificial Intelligence," offered by UTeM, and the syllabus is presented in Table 3.3. The FAQ of the course can be inserted into the knowledge base by means of backward log file analysis by the botmaster, by reading the logged conversations and searching for frequently asked questions in the dialogue and adding the answers to the knowledge base using AIML file. This ensures that the most frequent requests are taken into account. AAA files form the brain of the award-winning conversation boat ALICE. The availability of these files for free download on Google Code makes cloning the brain of ALICE easy. An AIML file can be created with any text editor such as Notepad + + and stored with the extension "aiml." The knowledge of the course is a derivation of a course XL file with an IML file.

sections.heading: 3.4.3 AIML Interpreter
sections.text: MOOC-bot uses program O as an AIML interpreter. Program O is an AIML engine written in PHP and uses MySQL database to store the information of the boat, including the AIML files used to generate the boat's responses. Program O is suitable for MOOC-Bot because it is implemented in a web environment that can be run independently and thus allows integration into the MOOCs website. Text or speech input from the chat interface is processed by the interpreter by performing pattern matching with the AIML content in the knowledge base using depth scanning. The first matching response is returned to the chat interface.Support for recursion in AIML makes it simple, yet powerful in pattern matching.

sections.heading: 3.4.4 MOOCs Website
sections.text: The MOOCs website is an initiative of UTeM to provide large open online courses to students. It is hosted for the prototype at http: / / ainibot.com / bot / mooc.php. A student can enroll in a course, download lecture notes, create quizzes, submit assignments and participate in a forum from here. A student's progress can also be tracked and monitored by the instructor. Integration of the MOOC bot chat interface into this website complements the role of the website.

sections.heading: 3.5 Summary
sections.text: In fact, most of them will be able to survive on their own.

sections.heading: 4.3 Knowledge Base Creation
sections.text: For the purpose of the prototype, only "MITI 5113 Artificial Intelligence" courses are added. For FAQ knowledge, the answers can be added from time to time by studying the conversation logs. As for general knowledge, note ALICE AIML (AAA) files from ALICE AI Foundation provide the convenience of cloning their general knowledge in MOOC Bot. More general knowledge that is not available in AAA files is also added to make MOOC-Bot smarter in dealing with general questions. There are two ways to add knowledge to the knowledge base. First, the knowledge can be made available directly in the user interface of Program O.

sections.heading: 4.4 Chat Interface
sections.text: The standard chat interface provided by Program O, as illustrated in Figure 4.16, can be used for initial development, but integration with MOOC's website requires designing a more appropriate chat interface that matches the website. Furthermore, the chat interface must be equipped with the Web Speech API for speech recognition and synthesis, as it was not included in Program O. The chat interface designed for MOOC's website is shown in Figure 4.21. The "webkitSpeechRecognition" object and the "SpeechSynthesisUtterance" object must be added to the JavaScript of the chat interface for speech recognition and synthesis, both of which are currently supported only in the Google Chrome and Apple Safari browsers (Walther, 2015). Figure 4.22 shows the voice recognition code snippet, and Figure 4.23 shows the voice synthesis code snippet used in MOOC messages.

sections.heading: 4.5 Summary
sections.text: Software installation and development environment are critical to ensuring that the development work can be carried out smoothly. To develop the MOOC bot, the knowledge base plays an important role in determining the intelligence of the conversational bot. Therefore, sufficient knowledge must be added to ensure that most queries can be processed. MOOC Boat's chat interface is designed to complement MOOC's website while providing the user with the convenience of real-time interaction. With speech recognition and speech synthesis, users have alternative input and output methods for conversation. CHAPTER 5EVALUATION AND RESULT5.1 IntroductionThis chapter explains the evaluation process and outcome of the MOOC bott.After MOOC Bot prototype has been prepared, it is important to evaluate and improve its performance whenever necessary. In this study, the black box approach is used to evaluate the MOOC Bot replies.

sections.heading: 5.3 Dataset
sections.text: Data sets are required to examine the answers generated by the MOOC bot in the black box evaluation, selecting a hundred past competition questions used in the CBC and the Loebner Prize. Source of data sets for the CBC is available at www.chatterboxchallenge.com, while the Loebner Prize is available at http: / / www.loebner.net / Prizef / loebner-prize.html. Table 5.1 and Table 5.2 show the CBC and Loebner Prize data sets used in the evaluation.

sections.heading: 5.4 Measurement
sections.text: Scoring guidelines used in CBC, as shown in Table 5.3.Guidelines in Table 5.3, are shown in Figure 5.1.

sections.heading: 5.5 Results
sections.text: This is the question of whether it is a 'yes', a 'no', a 'no', a 'no', a 'no', a 'no', a 'no', a 'no', a 'no', a 'no', a 'no', a 'no', a 'no', a 'no', a 'no', a 'no', a 'no', a 'no'.

sections.heading: 5.6 Summary
sections.text: In fact, we are in a position to set out to find a solution that will enable us to achieve our objectives.

sections.heading: 6.4 Limitations
sections.text: MOOC-bot depends on third-party technology such as Program Oas the AIML interpreter and Web Speech API for speech recognition and speech synthesis. Therefore, errors or limitations in these programs are also reflected on MOOC-bot. Among the deficiencies of Program O that were detected during development, sometimes includes the use of punctuation marks in the queries that can affect the results that are returned. Web Speech API is currently supported only by the Google Chrome and Apple Safari browsers. In addition, the need to give the application permission to use the speech recognition microphone after each pause could discourage the user from using it.

sections.heading: 6.5 Conclusion
sections.text: The evaluation results showed that MOOC-Bot has great potential to be a conversation bot that can interact with end users. Although the knowledge in this study is limited to a single course, further courses may be added in the future to offer a wider range of courses in MOOCs. Advantages of the MOOC boat, such as the 24-hour service, which can operate in different time zones, have knowledge in multiple areas, and a conversation bot can be used from multiple locations simultaneously, have outweighed the existing limitations, which are mainly due to external factors.

sections.heading: 6.6 Future Work
sections.text: One example is the provision of tutoring services in MOOCs to help students in their learning process. For example, the Conversation bot can help students with exercises or quizzes by providing explanations as needed. As for the limitation of speech recognition in this research, other technologies that are not browser-type can be explored for better results.

sections.heading: 6.7 Summary
sections.text: This chapter summarizes and concludes the overall progress of the study. The benefits and limitations are also discussed to provide better insights into a conversation bot. Future work is also proposed as a possible next step in this research.

referenceMentions.context: Among the prominent MOOCs providers are Coursera, edX and Udacity (Peco and Luján-Mora, 2013).

2 Massive Open Online Courses MOOCs were started in 2008 through the course, Connectivism and Connective Knowledge (CCK08) which was created and facilitated by George Siemens and Stephen Downes (Fini, 2009; Lowe, 2014).

2 Massive Open Online Courses MOOCs were started in 2008 through the course, Connectivism and Connective Knowledge (CCK08) which was created and facilitated by George Siemens and Stephen Downes (Fini, 2009; Lowe, 2014). Since then there has been tremendous development in MOOCs with millions of dollars of grants funded the experiments of variety principles, courses, and tools in MOOCs. Until today it is still developing and there is no sign of winding down. MOOC is considered an education revolution as it differs from traditional course by allowing large enrollments of students from all over the world regardless of prior learning. Some even defined it as courses being offered free of charge to anyone who are interested to learn. However, this is still a debatable topic as there is still a need of a business model to keep MOOCs sustainable (Dellarocas and Van Alstyne, 2013; Valentin, 2014). Anyhow, MOOCs is seen as the route to cheap education which will always be attractive to the public (Lowe, 2014). As far as the model is concerned, Siemen (2013) has classified three types of MOOCs: xMOOCs, cMOOCs, and quasi-MOOCs.
Jurenas (2014) has described the increased accessibility, enhanced student engagement, and lifelong learning opportunity as the advantages of MOOCs.

Jurenas (2014) has described the increased accessibility, enhanced student engagement, and lifelong learning opportunity as the advantages of MOOCs. LeCounte and Johnson (2014) opined that MOOCs provides the flexibility for working employees to train on specific skill-sets and also address skills gap problem for companies which need qualified applicants in fields such as accounting and finance, engineering, IT, etc.

Jurenas (2014) has described the increased accessibility, enhanced student engagement, and lifelong learning opportunity as the advantages of MOOCs. LeCounte and Johnson (2014) opined that MOOCs provides the flexibility for working employees to train on specific skill-sets and also address skills gap problem for companies which need qualified applicants in fields such as accounting and finance, engineering, IT, etc. On the other hand, the issues that MOOCs faced are the challenges of high dropout rates, sustainability, cheating and plagiarism (Siemen, 2013). On top of these, Jurenas (2014) also included the lack of individual instruction and impact on professional life of the instructor as the additional challenges.

Jurenas (2014) has described the increased accessibility, enhanced student engagement, and lifelong learning opportunity as the advantages of MOOCs. LeCounte and Johnson (2014) opined that MOOCs provides the flexibility for working employees to train on specific skill-sets and also address skills gap problem for companies which need qualified applicants in fields such as accounting and finance, engineering, IT, etc. On the other hand, the issues that MOOCs faced are the challenges of high dropout rates, sustainability, cheating and plagiarism (Siemen, 2013). On top of these, Jurenas (2014) also included the lack of individual instruction and impact on professional life of the instructor as the additional challenges. LeCounte and Johnson (2014) were of the view that the creditability of MOOCs is questionable due to the industry standards for pedagogy and evaluation criteria, not to mention the credit transferability of MOOCs among institutions.

Hayes and Ford (1995) argued that TT was not a sensible goal and considered it harmful to AI because AI researchers adopted it seriously as a long-range goal and motivation in the field which they think limiting AI’s sights.

Gunderson (1971), Searle (1980), Block (1981), French (1990), and Shieber (2006) have all questioned the sufficiency of TT as the criterion of intelligence which only relies on behavioral properties exhibited by a subject. Hayes and Ford (1995) argued that TT was not a sensible goal and considered it harmful to AI because AI researchers adopted it seriously as a long-range goal and motivation in the field which they think limiting AI’s sights. However, there were also researchers that defended TT such as Moor (1976) and Leiber (1995) who argued that the critics had misunderstood or misinterpreted the real value of TT.

Hayes and Ford (1995) argued that TT was not a sensible goal and considered it harmful to AI because AI researchers adopted it seriously as a long-range goal and motivation in the field which they think limiting AI’s sights. However, there were also researchers that defended TT such as Moor (1976) and Leiber (1995) who argued that the critics had misunderstood or misinterpreted the real value of TT. The Loebner Prize is the longest running annual contest based on TT but with some modification from the original TT (Shieber, 1994). Started since 1991, it was established by Dr. Hugh Loebner with the reward of $100,000 and a gold medal for the first program which able to respond indistinguishably from a human while each year the most humanlike computer will win an annual cash prize and a bronze medal (Loebner, n.d.). Shieber (1994) has criticized that the competition has no clear purpose or any useful outcome but Loebner (1994) responded by defending the need of the competition as a tool to measure the state of the art in AI.

However, there were also researchers that defended TT such as Moor (1976) and Leiber (1995) who argued that the critics had misunderstood or misinterpreted the real value of TT. Shieber (1994) has criticized that the competition has no clear purpose or any useful outcome but Loebner (1994) responded by defending the need of the competition as a tool to measure the state of the art in AI.

The Loebner Prize is the longest running annual contest based on TT but with some modification from the original TT (Shieber, 1994). Started since 1991, it was established by Dr. Hugh Loebner with the reward of $100,000 and a gold medal for the first program which able to respond indistinguishably from a human while each year the most humanlike computer will win an annual cash prize and a bronze medal (Loebner, n.d.). Shieber (1994) has criticized that the competition has no clear purpose or any useful outcome but Loebner (1994) responded by defending the need of the competition as a tool to measure the state of the art in AI. Saygin et. al. (2003) agreed that the award in Loebner Prize could influence research in AI by making people interested in creating TT-passing programs.

AIML may not be perfectly intelligent technology but its capability to deliver appropriate responses in domain-restricted areas (Schumaker et. al, 2006; Mikic et. al., 2008; Tan et. al, 2012; Ghose and Barua, 2013) is convincing enough to be the design behind MOOC-bot.

metadata.abstractText: Massive Online Open Courses (MOOCs) which were introduced in 2008 has since drawn attention around the world for both its advantages as well as criticism on its drawbacks. One of the issues in MOOCs which is the lack of interactivity with the instructor has brought conversational bot into the picture to fill in this gap. In this study, a prototype of MOOCs conversational bot, MOOC-bot is being developed and integrated into MOOCs website to respond to the learner’s enquiries using text or speech input. MOOC-bot is using the popular Artificial Intelligence Markup Language (AIML) to develop its knowledge base, leverage from AIML’s capability to deliver appropriate responses and can be quickly adapted to new knowledge domains. The system architecture of MOOC-bot consists of knowledge base along with AIML interpreter, chat interface, MOOCs website and Web Speech API to provide speech recognition and speech synthesis capability. The initial MOOC-bot prototype has the general knowledge from the past Loebner Prize winner ALICE, course’s frequent asked questions, and a course’s content offered by Universiti Teknikal Malaysia Melaka (UTeM). The evaluation of MOOC-bot based on the past competition questions from Chatterbox Challenge (CBC) and Loebner Prize has shown that it was able to provide correct answers most of the time during the test and demonstrated the capability to prolong the conversation. The advantages of MOOCbot such as able to provide 24-hour service that can serve different time zones, able to have knowledge in multiple domains, and can be shared by multiple sites simultaneously have outweighed its existing limitations.
metadata.creator: Microsoft® Word 2013
